definitions.definition: a small piece of paper, cloth, plastic, etc. attached to something to identify it or give information about it

examples.text: He put name tags on all his shirts.
a gift tag *(= tied to a present)*

phrases: something carries a price tag of…
something has a price tag of…

definitions.definition: an electronic device that can be attached to a person, animal or object so that police, researchers, etc. know where the person, etc. is

examples.text: The police use electronic tags to monitor the whereabouts of young offenders on probation.

definitions.definition: a name or phrase that is used to describe a person or thing in some way

examples.text: They are finally ready to drop the tag ‘the new Beatles’.
The president made several jokes in an attempt to shake off his ‘humourless’ tag.

definitions.definition: a word or phrase that is added to a sentence for emphasis, for example I do in Yes, I do
a set of letters or symbols that are put before and after a piece of text or data in order to identify it or show that it is to be treated in a particular way
a short quotation or saying in a foreign language

examples.text: the Latin tag ‘Si vis pacem, para bellum.’ *(= if you want peace, prepare for war)*

definitions.definition: a children’s game in which one child runs after the others and tries to touch one of them
a symbol or name used by a graffiti writer and painted in a public place

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 5 late Middle English (denoting a narrow hanging section of a decoratively slashed garment): of unknown origin; compare with dag. The verb dates from the early 17th cent. noun sense 6 mid 18th cent.: perhaps a variant of tig.
